newsitem.title: UK: Mercury World Mining denies to be wound up.
newsitem.headline: Mercury World Mining denies to be wound up.

text.p: Mercury World Mining Trust Plc denied a Sunday Telegraph report saying it was about to be wound up shortly because of its poor share performance.
The trust, which is run by Mercury Asset Management Group Plc, said it was bullish on the mining sector and added there was no shareholders' pressure for it to be liquidated.
"There is no truth in that (the newspaper article) at all," said Lough Callahan, managing director of Mercury Investment Trust Division.
"We've been meeting with investors and generally they share our belief that the outlook for mining shares is positive," he added.
Mercury World Mining Trust was launched in 1993 and its statutes oblige it to call an extraordinary meeting by the end of 1998, when shareholders have to vote wether to continue the company.

The trust saw its shares fall 6.1 percent in 1996, but fund manager Graham Birch told a briefing last month that the outlook for 1997 was favourable amid bullish expectations for world economic growth.
